title: About NBRC
body:
Created by the US Congress in 2008 (Farm Bill (P.L. 110-627), the Northern Border Regional Commission (NRBC) is a federal-state partnership whose mission is to help alleviate economic distress and encourage job creation throughout the northern regions in Maine, New Hampshire, Vermont, and New York.

Under the five‐year authorization measure, the new federal‐state regional commission was established to target resources to promote economic growth strategies and projects within the northern portions of the four‐state region of Maine, New Hampshire, New York and Vermont. These efforts focus on leveraging the public, private and philanthropic resources needed to develop and sustain the community building blocks for economic competitiveness and development in this highly distressed region, such as: transportation and basic infrastructure, job skills training and entrepreneurial development, comprehensive strategy development, advanced technologies and telecommunications, and sustainable energy solutions.

The Commission

The Commission's Grant Programs cover the following counties:

New York Maine Vermont New Hampshire
Cayuga Androscoggin Caledonia Carool
Clinton Aroostook Essex Coos
Essex Franklin Franklin Grafton
Franklin Hancock Grand Isle Sullivan
Fulton Knox Lamoille  
Hamilton Oxford Orleans  
Herkimer Penobscot    
Jefferson Piscataquis    
Lewis Somerset    
Madison Waldo    
Oneida Washington    
Oswego      
Seneca      
St. Lawrence

title: The Commission
body:
The Commission’s grant programs cover:

Maine: Twelve counties including Androscoggin, Aroostook, Franklin, Hancock, Kennebec, Knox, Oxford, Penobscot, Piscataquis, Somerset, Waldo, and Washington.

New Hampshire: Four counties including Carroll, Coos, Grafton and Sullivan.

Vermont: Six counties including Caledonia, Essex, Franklin, Grand Isle, Lamoille, and Orleans.

New York: Fourteen counties including Cayuga, Clinton, Essex, Franklin, Fulton, Hamilton, Herkimer, Jefferson, Lewis, Madison, Oneida, Oswego, Seneca, and St. Lawrence.

title: Local Development Districts
body:
In addition to the involvement of federal and state officials, the Commission model includes a network of local development districts that serve as the lead organizations at the sub‐state, multi-county regional level. The Commission is required by law to use the existing network of economic development districts designated by the U.S. Economic Development Administration (EDA) to assist the Commission in:

  • Conducting outreach activities to local governments, community development groups, business organizations and the general public
  • Identifying, assessing and facilitating projects and programs to promote economic development
  • Serving as a liaison between state and local governments, nonprofit organizations and the private sector

title: News
body: The Northern Border Regional Commission (NBRC) is helping communities in the states of Maine, New Hampshire, New York and Vermont. Read below for more details.
